Issues.Title: [ivy] using a template reference before its declaration causes ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Angular 9-rc.9 with Ivy ### Is this a regression? This issue is present only when Ivy is enabled. I have to say that I am not 100% sure it's a bug. It could be the pattern we have been using might not have been supported by Angular in the first place. But I have my own doubts as I explained below. ### Description Below is a simplified reproduction of the pattern that's causing the `ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError` error. The following snippet would work just in any Angular version as long as Ivy is not enabled: ```html

Greetings, {{hello.name}}!

``` As you can see, I'm simply template-referencing a component and interpolating its `name` property right above it. One thing to note here is that if you move the interpolation down below the `hello-comp`, I see there is no error: ```html

Greetings, {{hello.name}}!

``` So basically, Ivy is not happy when the template reference is used before its declaration. However, we had been using this pattern without any issues before Ivy. Also, I suspected that this pattern (using a template reference before its declaration) could have been something Angular has never supported. But in the documentation, I read these: - _The scope of a reference variable is the entire template._ - _You can refer to a template reference variable anywhere in the component's template_ So it seems to me at least using a template reference before its declaration has always been supported/allowed. But when Ivy is enabled, it starts throwing the error. As such, I am suspecting this could be another ivy related bug. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-8-template-reference-interpolation
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[ivy] using a template reference before its declaration causes ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError" (#34821)

Issues.Title: Cannot run npm install on existing angular project
Issues.Body:
I have an existing angular project that was working just a couple of months ago and checked into git repo. I got a new macbook running Mojave, installed node and angular cli globally. Issues.Title: SkipSelf annotation to get parent component Injector no longer working in Ivy (Angular 9 rc.9)
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core ### Is this a regression? Yes, with Angular 8 this was still possible. ### Description I have a component B that is a child of component A. With previous Angular versions I was able to inject the `Injector` of component A into component B by simply using the `@SkipSelf` annotation on the injected service. With that, I could then resolve services in the context of the parent component. In my use case, both A and B provide the same injection token with different fixed values and component B needs to know what this value was for its parent component. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-parent-injector-gx5pha The example on StackBlitz is of course in Angular 8 (since I can't seem to do Angular 9 rc projects) and works as expected. The output on the console is: 

this is "HELLO COMPONENT" and parent has name "THIS IS ROOT"
this is "HELLO COMPONENT" and parent has name "THIS IS ROOT"
When I download the example and upgrade it to Angular 9 rc.9 I get different output: 

this is "HELLO COMPONENT" and parent has name "THIS IS ROOT"
this is "HELLO COMPONENT" and parent has name "HELLO COMPONENT"
The second line is produced with the parent `Injector` injection approach. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** I tested this with Angular 9 rc.7, rc.8 and rc.9 and the example fails in all of them. **Anything else relevant?** In the past I have tried other aproaches to solve this issue, one of them was to use the `Injector.get` method and specifying the `InjectFlags` argument as documented in the [Injector](https://angular.io/api/core/Injector). It seems that in all versions of Angular (that I tested), the injector instance that I get when requesting an `Injector` on a component simply _ignores_ the inject flags - in the source code I can see that the method simply does not use this argument. Somehow I find this very weird since the documentation does not seem to mention that.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SkipSelf annotation to get parent component Injector no longer working in Ivy (Angular 9 rc.9)" (#34819)

Issues.Title: Canceling an in-progress JSONP request causes "callback undefined" console error
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/common/http ### Is this a regression? No ### Description It looks like HttpClientJsonpModule deletes the JSONP callback function for a request immediately upon cancellation. If the request was still in progress, an error is logged in the console when it completes because the function doesn't exist. This issue occurs when the time between requests is usually lower than the time a request takes to complete. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://angular-c6oeqi.stackblitz.io https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-c6oeqi ## üî• Exception or Error 

Uncaught ReferenceError: ng_jsonp_callback_16 is not defined

Issues.Title: fix: work around 'noImplicityAny' incompatibility due to ts3.7 update
Issues.Body:
Typescript 3.7 now emits d.ts files for getters differently than prior versions,
and there seems to be a bug in how it strips private types without replacing them
with explicit 'any' type. This then leads to compilation failures in projects compiled
against our packages that don't have skipLibCheck turned on but do have strict or
noImplicitAny check on.

I'm working around this by marking the affected getters as @Internal and
adding a test to prevent future regressions.

Typescript bug report: https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/36216
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix: work around 'noImplicityAny' incompatibility due to ts3.7 update" (#34798)

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): do not collect private declarations from external packages
Issues.Body:
Previously, while trying to build an `NgccReflectionHost`'s `privateDtsDeclarationMap`, `computePrivateDtsDeclarationMap()` would try to collect exported declarations from all source files of the program (i.e. without checking whether they were within the target entry-point, as happens for declarations in `.d.ts` files).

Most of the time, that would not be a problem, because external packages would be represented as `.d.ts` files in the program. But when an external package had no typings, the JS files would be used instead. As a result, the `ReflectionHost` would try to (unnecessarilly) parse the file in order to extract exported declarations, which in turn would be harmless in most cases.

There are certain cases, though, where the `ReflectionHost` would throw an error, because it cannot not parse the external package's JS file. This could happen, for example, in `UmdReflectionHost`, which expects the file to contain exactly one statement. See #34544 for more details on a real-world failure.

This commit fixes the issue by ensuring that `computePrivateDtsDeclarationMap()` will only collect exported declarations from files within the target entry-point.

Jira issue: [FW-1794](https://angular-team.atlassian.net/browse/FW-1794)

Fixes #34544.

##
For good measure, I have also tested it on the `ngcc-validation` repo (angular/ngcc-validation#777) and [nothing broke][1].

[1]: https://circleci.com/workflow-run/6c3c8973-665c-4f25-ae33-5df4d592cf01
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): do not collect private declarations from external packages" (#34811)

Issues.Title: [ivy] ngClass can clash with other class setters, resulting in invalid "[MAP]" class
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core or @angular/common 9.0.0-rc.8 ### Is this a regression? Yes, it works with Ivy disabled. ### Description Using the `[ngClass]` directive alongside other class setters can result in the class becoming (or containing) an invalid `[MAP]` value. For example, the following components: ```ts export class ChildComponent { @HostBinding("class.FromChild") isChild = true; } ``` ```html ``` One would expect both `FromChild` and `FromParent` classes to be applied. This is the case in View but not Ivy. In VE: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8922125/72481890-f9a2f680-384f-11ea-9aca-9f8c4f4228b8.png) In Ivy: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8922125/72481697-75507380-384f-11ea-9eb0-eace2c9371a2.png) The same thing _can_ also happen for `class` attribute bindings, but I couldn't get a simple reproduction and it's fairly easy to avoid. Host-bound classes are useful for shared components and UI libraries though so this seems like a more valid use case to me. This can be worked around by only setting attributes in `HostBinding`s and using attribute selectors for css instead. If that's the accepted solution feel free to close this ticket as working as intended. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction This branch of this repo: https://github.com/henry-alakazhang/angular-ivy-repros/tree/ngclass-hostbinding-clash ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 9.0.0-rc.8
Node: 12.4.0
OS: linux x64

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): catch FatalDiagnosticError thrown from preanalysis phase
Issues.Body:
Component's decorator handler exposes `preanalyze` method to preload async resources (templates, stylesheets). The logic in preanalysis phase may throw `FatalDiagnosticError` errors that contain useful information regarding the origin of the problem. However these errors from preanalysis phase were not intercepted in TraitCompiler, resulting in just error message text be displayed. This commit updates the logic to handle FatalDiagnosticError and transform it before throwing, so that the result diagnostic errors contain the necessary info.

Resolves #34725.

Issues.Title: Reactive forms do not work with ControlValueAccessor when ControlValueAccessor's type is array.
Issues.Body:
Reproducer can be found here: https://stackblitz.com/github/jvanheesch/angular-reactive-forms-array-model

Explanation:
We have a legacy codebase with custom form components such as CustomFormComponentComponent.
This component works perfectly fine with ng-model & template-driven forms [see in reproducer: select 'Template driven' choice].

Our codebase is now transitioning from template-driven forms to reactive forms.
However, when passing an array to CustomFormComponentComponent using formControlName, somehow (to our surprise) the ControlValueAccessor's val is set to the first element in the array.
This breaks the component, as its ngFor requires an array rather than a regular object.

We really don't want to change our existing custom components, but so far the only workaround we came up with is CustomFormComponentWorkAroundComponent [see in reproducer: select 'Template driven' choice].
Instead of passing an array, we now pass an object containing a single property containing the array.

Could anyone please confirm whether or not this is a bug?
If it's not a bug (i.e. "working as intended"), we'd love to hear if there's an appropriate way to get the desired result (working with reactive forms) without modifying our existing components (ControlValueAccessors).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Reactive forms do not work with ControlValueAccessor when ControlValueAccessor's type is array." (#34800)

TypeChecker._update: 0.144ms TypeChecker._createOrUpdateProgram.ng.createProgram: 360.438ms TypeChecker.gatherDiagnostics.ng.getTsSemanticDiagnostics: 9293.606ms ``` Above numbers are for large monorepo app which source code contains about 160k typescript lines of code and 950 Components ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/... ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: The command ng serve is not responding to changes to ng module
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command

- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n

### Description

`ng serve` either is not responding to changes made to the `declarations` property of an `NgModule`.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
1. `ng new pokemon --routing=false --style=css`
2. `ng generate component pokedex`
3. set up `pokedex` to be used by the root component
4. `ng serve`
5. remove `pokedex` from the `declarations` field of the `NgModule` in `app.module.ts`

### Expected
The app crashes
### Actual
The app continues working

### Additional Information
Restarting `ng serve` fixes the issue.
This also works vice-versa, so if the application is crashing due to `pokedex` _not_ being in the `declarations` of `app.module.ts`, adding it without restarting `ng serve` will still be crashing.

## üåç Your Environment
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25158423/70344220-fe669a80-180d-11ea-87ef-afb74aacd87a.png)

## Demo
I've created a demo project [here](https://github.com/wagnermaciel/Pokedex).
To reproduce this issue
1. `git clone https://github.com/wagnermaciel/Pokedex.git`
2. `npm install`
3. `ng serve`
4. Go to http://localhost:4200/pikachu
4. remove `PokedexComponent` from the `declarations` of the `NgModule` in `src/app.app.module.ts`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The command ng serve is not responding to changes to ng module" (#34813)

Issues.Title: `ng e2e --debug`
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [X] e2e

### Description
I've been looking for means to debug faulty e2e Protractor tests, however I don't see a means of accomplishing this in the Angular CLI, or a documented solution.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Ideally, I'd like to see some kind of `ng e2e --debug` or `ng e2e --inspect` which builds/runs the application, starts Protractor, and opens up a debugging port. If there is a way to break after test files are loaded, so I can set breakpoints without manually adding a `debugger;` statement, that would be great too.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Most of the material I've found online tells me to call Protractor directly, via something like `node --inspect node_modules/.bin/protractor e2e/protractor.conf.js`. This has a couple problems to me:

1. This is a leaky abstraction.
    * We can do every other execution necessary via the CLI, but not debug e2e tests. As a tangential example, take a look at this [`package.json` scripts configuration](https://github.com/dgp1130/chatter/blob/ng/services/ng-frontend/package.json#L4) I have, all of which just uses `ng` directly, **except** for debugging e2e tests.
    * We do seem to leak Protractor in a few other places (such as the configuration file).
    * Subtle implementation changes in `ng e2e` could cause the debug command to need to be changed. For instance, should I update `webdriver-manager` before running?
1. I don't see any official documentation or stance on how to debug e2e tests; everything I've found is community built.
1. Running Protractor directly also does not boot up the actual application, so a separate `ng serve` command is necessary.
    * I didn't realize this and lost a lot of time debugging, confused why it worked previously and suddenly stopped today. Turns out I had the server running the background last time and didn't realize that was a dependency!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`ng e2e --debug`" (#16683)

Issues.Title: [RFC][PostCSS] Ability to configure PostCSS using config
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request - Ability to configure PostCSS using config


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [x] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [x] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [x] doc

### Description
There a bunch of requests regarding ability to configure PostCSS plugins:
#15766
#8427 
#10076

My proposal more practical and I could prepare PRs for it.

CLI uses PostCSS via `postcss-loader` it has a configuration [here](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/styles.ts), however plugins list is encapsulated in a function and then applied to multiple loaders (global styles, component styles with/without preprocessors). [`postcss-loader`](https://github.com/postcss/postcss-loader) has a `config` parameter that allows to specify the path to look for PostCSS configuration files (internally it uses [`postcss-load-config`](https://github.com/michael-ciniawsky/postcss-load-config)) and optional context objects to pass to js config files. If CLI will use config configuration for `postcss-loader` it will give the ability to extend/replace plugins, parser, etc. even more it will allow overriding config for specific project/ library/ any folder.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
File: `packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/styles.ts`

PostCSS loader could look like this

```ts
{
  loader: require.resolve('postcss-loader'),
  options: {
      ident: buildOptions.extractCss ? 'extracted' : 'embedded',
      // Config that replaces plugins param
     config: {
         path: root, // root folder path provided by BuilderContext
         ctx: {
           angularCliPlugins: // Here we could pass CLI specific plugins condigs or plugins itself
         }
     },
      sourceMap:
          cssSourceMap && !buildOptions.extractCss && !buildOptions.sourceMap.hidden
              ? 'inline'
               : cssSourceMap,
    },
 },
```

In the root we will have a `postcss.config,js` (it couls be `.postcssrc.js` as well) file:

```js
module.exports = (ctx) => ({
  parser: ctx.parser ? 'sugarss' : false,
  plugins: {
    'postcss-import': ctx.angularCliPlugins.postcssImportOptions,
    'custom-angular-cli-plugin': ctx.angularCliPlugins.otherOptions,
    'autoprefixer': true, // users could opt-out, ex. if postcss-preset-env used
    'postcss-plugin': ctx.options.plugin
  }
})
```

Users will get full control of PostCSS with that configuration, could make it dynamic with `ctx`, etc.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?


Another option is to pass configuration from `angular.json`, but IMO not the best idea as it will make it more complex + CLI exposes configs for `browserslist`, `tslint`, etc. with defaults but users can customize them.

[`ngx-build-plus`](https://github.com/manfredsteyer/ngx-build-plus) could replace part of webpack config, but you might need to hook up into few places (global styles, preprocessor styles loaders and rely on that exact structure of `webpack` config) and you have no control over plugins provided by CLI since they are created with a function call.

[`angular-builders/custom-webpack`](https://github.com/just-jeb/angular-builders/tree/master/packages/custom-webpack) has pretty same limitations and open issues related to PostCSS, [see](https://github.com/just-jeb/angular-builders/issues/634)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[RFC][PostCSS] Ability to configure PostCSS using config" (#16681)

Issues.Title: css minification eating single quotes in production - breaking grid
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Description The CSS minifier used in --prod building eats the apostrophes rendering broken css. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Minimal reproduction `ng new something` - pick css app.component.css 
.my-grid {
    grid: 'test' 'test2';
}
.my-grid2 {
    grid: 'test'
          'test2';
}
.my-grid3 {
    grid: 'test' 1fr
          'test2' 1fr / 1fr;
}
@media screen and (max-width: 500px){
    .my-grid {
        grid: 'test test2' / 1fr 2fr;
  
  }
}`
Using 
ng build --prod
## üî• Exception or Error The above app.component.css gets rendered in the main*.js to: 
`[".my-grid[_ngcontent-%COMP%], .my-g
    rid2[_ngcontent-%COMP%]{grid:test test2}.my-grid3[_ngcontent-%COMP%]{grid:test 1fr test2 
    1fr / 1fr}@media screen and (max-width:500px){.my-grid[_ngcontent-%COMP%]{grid:'test tes
    t2' / 1fr 2fr}}"]`
Notice that some of the apostrophes get removed and some don't. The grid statements without the quotes (apostrophes) are not rendered by the browser, yelding layouts that work fine in development but not in production. ## üåç Your Environment 



Angular CLI: 8.3.22
Node: 12.13.1
OS: linux x64
Angular: 8.2.14
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.803.22
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.803.22
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.803.22
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.803.22
@angular-devkit/core              8.3.22
@angular-devkit/schematics        8.3.22
@angular/cli                      8.3.22
@ngtools/webpack                  8.3.22
@schematics/angular               8.3.22
@schematics/update                0.803.22
rxjs                              6.4.0
typescript                        3.5.3
webpack                           4.39.2
**Anything else relevant?** This is clearly a bug with clean-css package. But as it took me a long time to debug my code until I was sure it was angular compilation, and then using /* clean-css ignore:start*/ ... /* clean-css ignore:end*/ to make sure it was clean-css and because I couldn't fight nothing on this on google or stackoverflow I thought it might post this to help if others are suffering from this problem. The /* clean-css ignore:start*/ ... /* clean-css ignore:end*/ work as a temp fix if you install clean-css ^=4.2
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "css minification eating single quotes in production - breaking grid" (#16674)

Issues.Body: This label is expected to be added by authors after the review once they have made final edits to the PR (per contributing guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#-submitting-a-pull-request-pr). The bot will never make additional edits from a review, so it is always ready to merge. This adds the "PR action: merge" label so it will show up correctly in the caretaker search for PRs ready to merge (https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#-submitting-a-pull-request-pr). Issues.Title: Ability to overwrite files while copying through assets array / Copying files in order
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
In an Angular CLI workspace with multiple apps you may also want to share multiple assets like images, favicons, etc across the multiple apps existing in the workspace. In the `assets` array of the `angular.json` the path to the shared files and folders can be given and the files are being copied in the concrete build of the separate apps. 

If one app now wants to have it's own file - e.g. an own different favicon or logo - the path to the `app/assets` can be provided in the `assets` array of the `angular.json` as well _after_ the shared files path. Unfortunately the order of the paths is not respected and the concrete apps asset files are not overwriting the shared assets during the build/copying pahse, although they have the same name.

```
"assets": [
	{
		"glob": "**/*.*",
		"input": "libs/shared/assets",
		"output": "/"
	}, 
	{
		"glob": "**/*.*",
		"input": "app/assets",
		"output": "/"
	},
],
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
It would be nice if the order of the array would be respected and files would get overwritten if the filename and the output folder are the same.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
The only workaround I have seen so far is to point at the files explicitly. This worked in my tests:

```
"assets": [
	{
		"glob": "**/*.*", // <-- contains a logo.png
		"input": "libs/shared/assets",
		"output": "/"
	}, 
	{
		"glob": "logo.png",
		"input": "app/assets",
		"output": "/logo.png"
	},
],
```

But doing this for multiple files results in an unhandy and very difficult `angular.json` assets array.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ability to overwrite files while copying through assets array / Copying files in order" (#16670)

Issues.Title: NG 8 IE 11 & Differential Loading
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/ ... not sure cli? it's a build issue ### Description So there are a few things to track here: Specifically in IE11 If I build the linked project with the `tsconfig.json` target "es5" everything works. (baseline). If I build the project with `tsconfig.json` target "es2015" a few things do not work as I expect: 1. It builds both es2015 and es5 bundles. Strangely IE11 will load both the es2015 and the es5 bundles, when I expected it to just load the es5 bundle. Chrome correctly loads just the es2015 bundle. 2. The es5 bundle created when differential loading is enabled is larger than the es5 bundle created when ts.config is set to es5 and differential loading is off. In my small sample app the differences are not that large but in our production app the difference is substantial. I would have thought that the es5 differential loading bundle would be no bigger than the non differential loading use case. Differential loading No differential loading From the above images you can see that the main bundle for the base ES5 scenario is 282 but for the differential loading its 298. Again this is a small sample app, in our production app this is more pronounced. 3. The bundle created produces errors when running in IE11, loading ESRI maps. Again I find this strange as I would have assumed the es5 differential loading bundle would be equivalent to the bundle created when setting ts.config to es5, which works fine. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/vespertilian/ng8-ie11 build with npm run build serve the dist build with ng run serve-dist (might need to install http-server) change ts.config from es5 to es2015 to build the different packages. ## üî• Exception or Error Just for the third case

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/focus-trap) Add ConfigurableFocusTrap classes
Issues.Body:
ConfigurableFocusTrap is part of a new FocusTrap design that will trap more
than just tab focus.

This commit sets up the classes for the new design, and implements the primary
strategy for preventing focus outside the trap (an event listener that
refocuses the trap). Logic to trap screen reader focus and wrap tab
without the hidden tab stops will be in future commits. Migration of
cdkTrapFocus, MatDialog, etc. will also be in future commits.

This commit does not enable ConfigurableFocusTrap anywhere.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk/focus-trap) Add ConfigurableFocusTrap classes" (#18201)

Issues.Title: MatMenu positioned incorrectly (Chrome on Google Pixel)
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://angular-8-material-menu-size-bug.stackblitz.io

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open StackBlitz example in Chrome on Google Pixel device
2. Tap the second "Trigger Menu" button
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The rendered menu instance to be positioned at (or near) the top of the viewport so that you are able to scroll and view all 99 items in the list.

I expect this because it seems that when the content of the `MatMenu` instance exceeds the height of the viewport, the menu is sized to roughly the height of the viewport (less a gap of `48px`).


#### Actual Behavior

The menu opens below the button, but is still sized to roughly the height of the viewport. This causes a part of the menu to overflow the bottom of the screen, and you are unable to scroll to see all items within the menu.

It seems to present whenever the trigger is within the top half of the screen (but low down enough to cause the menu to overflow the bottom). Tap the third trigger to see it working correctly.


#### Environment

- Angular: ^8.0.0
- CDK/Material: ^8.2.2
- Browser(s): Chrome 78
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Android 10, Pixel 4

#### Other notes

This works as expected (is positioned near the top of the viewport) on everything other than Chrome on Pixel devices. I've tested across various Pixel models and Android versions - it always shows up in this combo.

It does not present on Google Nexus devices (tested 6P).

Unfortunately I am only able to test one Chrome version (78) so I am unable to rule out that this is a Chrome bug.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatMenu positioned incorrectly (Chrome on Google Pixel)" (#18192)

Issues.Title: Consider switching from SystemJS to RequireJS
Issues.Body:
We should consider switching to RequireJS for consistency in the future. The Bazel karma rules already use it, and the `ts_devserver` does too.

It's unclear what limitations RequireJS brings, and what benefits it has. At first glance, I'm unsure if RequireJS provides a good way to lazily load modules (this worked good in SystemJS).

Also it's unclear how flexible the configuration file is. We should compare the pros/cons and decide based on that, if it makes sense to use RequireJS. It might be also worth exploring other tools/loaders. e.g. there is a webpack rule for Bazel.. but I don't think it's applicable.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Consider switching from SystemJS to RequireJS" (#18189)

Issues.Title: Custom directive event not firing inside matMenuContent
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-kywfzy
I have written a custom directive which opens a confirmation dialog when click event is fired on its host element. When user confirms action, it emits event to which I subscribe in template. Attaching this directive to elements inside lazily-rendered material menu has **no** effect.

#### Expected Behavior

Custom events should fire like they do with "eagerly" rendered menus.

#### Actual Behavior

Events don't fire

```
<!-- Simple button with custom event, works fine -->
<button mat-button alert-confirm (confirmEvent)="onDelete()">
  <mat-icon color="warn">delete</mat-icon>Delete
</button>

<!-- Default menu, works fine -->
<button mat-icon-button [matMenuTriggerFor]="menu">
  <mat-icon>more_vert</mat-icon>
</button>
<mat-menu #menu="matMenu">
  <button mat-menu-item alert-confirm (confirmEvent)="onDelete()">
    Delete
  </button>
</mat-menu>

<!-- Lazily rendered menu, doesn't work -->
<button mat-icon-button [matMenuTriggerFor]="itemActions">
  <mat-icon>more_vert</mat-icon>
</button>
<mat-menu #itemActions="matMenu">
  <ng-template matMenuContent>
    <button mat-menu-item alert-confirm (confirmEvent)="onDelete()">
      Delete
    </button>
  </ng-template>
</mat-menu>
```

![https://i.imgur.com/6cjbZYm.gif](https://i.imgur.com/6cjbZYm.gif)

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2
- CDK/Material: 8.2
- Browser(s): Google Chrome 77

Issues.Title: fix(expansion): unable to toggle disabled panel via methods
Issues.Body:
In our expansion panel readme we state that a disabled panel can still be toggled and this is partially true, because it works only for toggling through the `expanded` property, but not via the `open`, `close` and `toggle` methods since they're inherited from the CDK `AccordionItem`. These changes override the methods so that we can allow them to work on disabled panels. We can't make this change safely for the CDK accordion item, because it doesn't have a panel header which means that we have to assume that all calls to the methods are user-generated.

Fixes #18171.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(expansion): unable to toggle disabled panel via methods" (#18181)

Issues.Title: CDKDragAndDrop: Collapse cdkDropList item contents on cdkDragStarted event
Issues.Body:
<!--------

The Angular team can't provide general troubleshooting help. However, the extended community of
users can provide more help: 

StackOverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/angular-material2
Gitter: https://gitter.im/angular/material2
Google Groups: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/angular-material2

Issues should capture only bug reports and feature requests. However, we understand that 
it is not always clear whether an issue is caused by a bug or incorrect usage of a feature/component.

Most support requests will be automatically closed. If the answer is quickly obvious, though, we 
might be able to provide a brief answer.

-------->
### (Marked as troubleshooting since I wasn't sure if there was a known solution for this case)
#### What are you trying to do?

Collapse/hide the contents of all items in a cdkDropList upon starting a drag event, leaving a condensed view of labels that is easier to sort.

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

When starting the drag event, all items collapse except for the item currently being dragged, causing issues in the list placeholder when attempting to drop an item.  Once the drop event is complete, the dropped item collapses and the list returns to normal.

#### Reproduction

StackBlitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-bt4kvt?file=app%2Fapp.component.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. Set up a cdkDropList with items that contain a title and collapsible content panel.
2. Set the cdkDragStarted event for the list items to collapse all of the content panels.
3. Make sure all items in the list are expanded.
4. Begin dragging one of the items.
  
#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.0
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CDKDragAndDrop: Collapse cdkDropList item contents on cdkDragStarted event" (#18179)

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/testing): Allow custom `querySelectorAll` method
Issues.Body:
This allows the user to drop in a shadow-piercing version of
`querySelectorAll` to handle components that use
`ViewEncapsulation.ShadowDom`

I've gotten a unit test working that uses [kagekiri](https://github.com/salesforce/kagekiri) to demonstrate working with components that use `ViewEncapsulation.ShadowDom`.

It should be possible to get an e2e test working using the same library, but I had some difficulty getting it set up. The librariy's `package.json` specifies the common js module as the `main`. The e2e test kept loading that instead of the umd, and I wasn't sure how to configure it
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk/testing): Allow custom `querySelectorAll` method" (#18178)

Issues.Title: Option to inherit dimensions when using *cdkDragPreview
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description
Add an option to inherit the dimensions (width, height) of the draggable element when using a custom preview template.

#### Use Case
It would be really useful in cases where the custom preview element is similar to the source element.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Option to inherit dimensions when using *cdkDragPreview" (#18177)

Issues.Title: Option to position *cdkDragPreview under the cursor
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description
When using custom preview templates with *cdkDragPreview, the preview is always positioned next to the cursor. This behaviour is different to using the default preview where the preview is positioned relative the pickup location.

I had a look in the code and removing the if shorthand at [https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-ref.ts#L753](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-ref.ts#L753) solves this. Checking the `_getPointerPositionInElement` method I couldn't find any reason why it wouldn't work with custom preview templates.

#### Use Case
This would be improve UX when using a custom preview template that has similar dimensions to the root element.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Option to position *cdkDragPreview under the cursor" (#18176)

Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental): errors with latest MDC canary version
Issues.Body: A few hours ago MDC switched all their Sass to use the new Sass modules (see https://github.com/material-components/material-components-web/commit/faa9af310d1a18ec2c183830c84eb14d0492feab). This breaks our MDC components since they've been set up to use global Sass variables. These changes switch all the imports to the `.import` files which use the old approach for exposing variables.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material-experimental): errors with latest MDC canary version" (#18173)
